lessonOverview.title: Unit 5 - Lesson 1
structures: B: Yes, he/she is. / No, he/she isn’t. He’s/She’s short.
B: Yes, they are. / No, they aren’t. They’re short.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six appearance adjectives (tall, short, pretty, handsome, old, young) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show flashcards of people with different appearances. Students match adjectives from the board (e.g., tall, old) to the pictures.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about appearance using “Is he/she ___?” / “Are they ___?” and respond with “Yes, he/she is.” / “No, he/she isn’t. He’s/She’s ___.” or “Yes, they are.” / “No, they aren’t. They’re ___.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Pair work: Show a classmate card. Ask: “Is he short?” Partner responds using full sentence: “No, he isn’t. He’s tall.” Swap roles.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structures “Is he/she ___?” / “Yes, he/she is.” / “No, he/she isn’t. He’s/She’s ___.” and “Are they ___?” / “Yes, they are.” / “No, they aren’t. They’re ___.” to talk about appearance.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write questions: “Is she…?” / “Are they…?” on the board. Use two puppet props or pictures for modelling and practice in groups.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
